Back in the spring, George and I started

of building tolerance to spicy peppers. We 
decided to eat part of a raw serrano pepper

every day to see if we could build our 
tolerance in a really short window of time.

And I didn't care about lactose. All I

which I had always heard was milk, but I ended 
up finding something better. More on that later.

To stop the burn, I wanted to first figure out how 
it works. So I did a little research. When you eat

something spicy, capsaicin will bind to your TRPV1 
receptors. So TRPV1 receptors are proteins that

are on some of your pain receptor cells. And when 
they're activated by capsaicin, a signal is sent

up to your brain that your brain then translates 
to I'm in a lot of pain. TRPV1 also detects

actual heat. And so it can be activated at 
temperatures above 109 degrees Fahrenheit.

And TRPV1 Isn't just in your mouth. It's in 
your digestive tract, your skin, your eyes,

it's all over the place. Remember that 
time you chopped a bunch of peppers and

then forgot to wash your hands before 
rubbing your eyes. Thank TRPV1. So what

we really need is something that can remove 
capsaicin from theTRPV1 receptor entirely.

Capsaicin is a nonpolar molecule like oil. It's 
not going to dissolve in water, which means

water won't wash it away all that well. Milk is 
supposedly the best thing for beating the heat.

And I'd always heard that it was because the fats 
in it that are nonpolar can actually clear out the

capsaicin, but is that really true? We wanted to 
see if we could test a few different variables--

protein, fat, and temperature to see if we could 
come up with the best cure for hot pepper burn.
